channel.title: 28th Annual Couchiching Conference, 1959
channel.description:
About two hundred attendees from various parts of the world have gathered to talk about and hear about changing Asia, a matter of great concern to all of us in the world today. Too often we in the West tend to judge the attitudes and actions of Asian countries only from our own standpoint. At this conference we have tried to avoid this and have invited personalities from different Asian countries to come and explain to us in their own terms what is happening in India, Japan, China, Indonesia, and elsewhere.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Changing Asia #4: Western influence on Asia
item.description: Tonight we're going to examine this western influence on Asia, setting it in historical perspective and trying to assess what kind of Asian society is going to emerge from the present confusion. This program features remarks by Y.P. Mei, (Mei, Yibao, 1900-1997), a scholar of Chinese philosophy.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Changing Asia #3: Asian roads to progress
item.description: Tonight we look to the future: the Asian road to progress as seen through Asian eyes and features speeches by L.N. Palar, former Indonesian ambassador to the United Nations; author Suyin Han; Islamic philosopher and scholar Fazlur Rahman; and C.S. Venkatachar, former secretary to the president of India.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Changing Asia #6: Sources of conflict between East and West
item.description: This session, introduced by the CBC's head of public affairs Frank Peers, features remarks by Harvard University professor Edwin O. Reischauer, who comments on the declining influence of the West in Asia and whether the sources of tension between the two regions relate to misunderstandings or a true clash of interests.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Changing Asia #1: Opening session
item.description: History and destiny are being shaped in Asia while the west is woefully ignorant of the forces that work in this area with more than a billion people in it, struggling to emancipate themselves from the shackles of the past. This opening session features a speech by Nirmal Chaudhuri, United Nations diplomatic correspondent for the Straits Times in Singapore.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Changing Asia #7: Asia and Western policy
item.description: This concluding session opened with a speech by J. Graham Parsons, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, on the subject of Asia and western policy: what have we done to meet the problems that have been created for the West by this dynamic young revolution that is underway, and how are we going to find that basis upon which both the West and Asia can operate for their mutual benefit?
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Changing Asia #5, Part 1: Will all Asia go Communist?
item.description: This program, hosted by Canadian politician and journalist René Lévesque, features remarks by Kazushige Hirasawa of The Japan Times on the Communist influence in Asia and whether the entire continent is likely to go Communist.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Changing Asia #5, Part 2: Will all Asia go Communist?
item.description: This program, hosted by Canadian politician and journalist René Lévesque, features remarks by Kazushige Hirasawa of The Japan Times on the Communist influence in Asia and whether the entire continent is likely to go Communist.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Changing Asia #2: Social change in Asia
item.description: Perhaps we in the West think of the problems facing Asia today inherently political or economic terms. But it's in the social structure of a country that many of the changes are felt most keenly. Tonight we're going to hear about some of the social changes that Asian countries--China in particular--are undergoing today. The opening speaker is Suyin Han, author of the autobiographical novel A Many-Splendored Thing.
item.dc:creator: Wilson, Bob
item.dc:subject: World Politics
